description: Reference species for γ-secretase complex comparison. The human γ-secretase complex is the most extensively studied and serves as the benchmark for understanding the structure and function of this critical enzyme complex involved in Alzheimer's disease pathogenesis.

Primary laboratory model organism for γ-secretase research. Mouse models have been instrumental in understanding the role of γ-secretase in neurodegeneration and development, with high sequence conservation to human proteins.

Important vertebrate model for developmental studies of γ-secretase function. Zebrafish possess functional γ-secretase complexes that play crucial roles in Notch signaling during embryonic development.

Classic genetic model organism where γ-secretase function was first characterized. Drosophila studies revealed the essential role of presenilin in Notch signaling and provided insights into the evolutionary conservation of the complex.
Simple model organism with a well-characterized γ-secretase complex. C. elegans studies have provided insights into the basic mechanisms of presenilin function and its role in development.

Model plant organism that lacks a traditional γ-secretase complex but contains presenilin-like proteins involved in different cellular processes, providing insights into the evolutionary origins of the complex.
